A book in this language likens the collective pursuit of a concept meaning "happiness" to body parts working together; that book contrasts ignorant, dissolute, turncoat, and straying places with the title Virtuous City. A philosopher who used this language illustrated his occasionalism with the example of a fire burning cotton. This language was used by a philosopher who advocated the "unity of the intellect" and was called "The (*) Commentator" by Aquinas. The Aristotelian influence on thinkers who used this language was attacked by a member of the Ash'ari tradition in The Incoherence of the Philosophers, which inspired a similarly-titled rebuttal. For 10 points, name this language used by Averroes ("uh-VAIR-roh-eez") and al-Ghazali.

3. They're not databases, but "federated" examples of these systems include ActivityPub and the subject of the non-meteorological ATmosphere Conference. "Wars" over these systems were lost by X.25 and the OSI model following Van Jacobson's development of a congestion control algorithm for one of these systems. One of these systems has a "loopback" value for self-reference that begins (*) "127." To avoid "exhaustion" of four-number dot-decimal notation values, the "v4" of one of these systems has been partially supplanted by "v6". A "secure" extension to one of these systems adds "S" to a four-letter acronym that appears in web addresses. For 10 points, name these network communication systems denoted by the "P" in "HTTP."

4. Norwegian composer Ola Gjeilo ("YAY-lo") frequently collaborates with one of these ensembles from Royal Holloway, University of London. Adrian Willaert ("VILL-art") wrote antiphonal ("an-TIFF-uh-nal") music featuring multiple of these ensembles while living in Venice. Composition students learn four-part writing by studying J. S. Bach's short preludes written and named for these ensembles. The Duke of Norfolk apocryphally challenged Thomas Tallis to write (*) Spem in Alium for eight of these ensembles. "Jesu ("YAY-zoo"), Joy of Man's Desiring" is an excerpt from a Bach cantata featuring one of these ensembles. The most common type of these large ensembles that often tune to a pitch pipe is called SATB. For 10 points, name these large vocal ensembles.

5. In the 1870s, a member of this family consolidated control over and greatly expanded the Homestake Mine near Deadwood. A century later, another member of this family who worked with Wendy Yoshimura shouted "I'm Tania!" while caught on camera robbing the Hibernia Bank in San Francisco. Bill Clinton pardoned that member of this family for that crime and several others she committed with the (*) Symbionese Liberation Army. Members of this family included the kidnapping victim Patty and her grandfather, who engaged in a circulation war with Joseph Pulitzer and sensationalized atrocity reports in Cuba before the Spanish-American War. In an 1874 painting, these people form a circle around an elderly (*) master with his hands atop a cane. One member of this family explains a poem in which Jesus is told that free will has bad effects by a clergyman in (*) Seville. A novice monk from this family follows Father Zosima. 8. A British cult celebrating this person was fueled by Harriet Martineau's novel The Hour and the Man. To keep up agricultural exports, this man's government issued the world's first national identification system. This man secured a namesake trade clause during the Quasi War a few years after he sent a letter mocking reforms announced by Commissioner Sonthonax ("sohn-toh-NAHKS"). Although this man ultimately died in the (*) French prison of Fort de Joux ("fohr de ZHOO"), he was victorious over André Rigaud ("ahn-DRAY ree-GO") in the War of the Knives. Two of this man's children were held as ransom by General Charles Leclerc ("SHARL le-CLAIR") in 1802 after Leclerc made peace with Henri Christophe ("ahn-REE cree-STOHF") and Jean-Jacques Dessalines ("deh-sah-LEEN"). For 10 points, name this leader of Haiti's slave insurrection.
ANSWER: Toussaint Louverture [or Toussaint Louverture; or Toussaint L'Ouverture; or François Dominique Toussaint; or Toussaint Breda]

11. According to Suetonius, the wealthy woman Cossutia was betrothed to this man before adulthood. Mamercus Aemilianus and Aurelius Cotta helped this man gain Sulla's forgiveness to undo his exile for refusing to divorce his wife, Cornelia. This man gave a funeral oration for both his aunt and his first wife, in which he asserted his family's descent from the goddess Venus. This man divorced his third wife, (*) Pompeia, because he suspected her of having had an affair with Clodius Pulcher ("POOL-care") during the Bona Dea festival. This man's last wife, Calpurnia, reportedly dreamt of his stabbing the night before he died. For 10 points, what Roman general had numerous affairs before the Ides of March?

Baddeley and Hitch proposed a model of this faculty, whose central executive controls a visuospatial sketchpad, an episodic buffer, and a phonological loop. This faculty's capacity is increased by (*) chunking. Nelson Cowan found that this faculty has a capacity of four, in contrast with George Miller's finding of a capacity of seven plus or minus two. This faculty is consolidated by the hippocampus. For 10 points, name this faculty that temporarily holds information, which is contrasted with a long-term counterpart.

These are the typical particles emitted alongside photons when Brillouin ("bree-WANN") scattering contributes to Stokes shift. Beyond the regime in which these particles' energy increases linearly with momentum, maxons and rotons arise. A superconducting "isotope effect" evidences the role of these particles in the association of electrons into (*) Cooper pairs. 17. Alanine scanning mutagenesis was introduced to inhibit this protein's binding to its namesake receptor. Deficiency in this protein is a childhood symptom of Prader–Willi syndrome, so injections of a version of this protein are a common treatment for it and for both SHOX deficiency and Turner syndrome. This protein is involved in a negative feedback loop in which it stimulates IGF-1 production in the liver. ANSWER: Bernardo de Gálvez [or Bernardo Vicente de Gálvez y Madrid, 1st Count of Gálvez; prompt on Galveston] [10e] Gálvez ordered the construction of Chapultepec Castle in what is now this capital city, which US forces captured from Santa Anna in 1847.
ANSWER: Mexico City [or Ciudad de México] [10m] Gálvez fielded the Regiment of Hibernia, composed of soldiers of this ethnicity.
After capturing Chapultepec, Winfield Scott executed 30 soldiers of this ethnicity who had defected to Mexico from the US.
ANSWER: Irish [or Irish American] (The 30 soldiers were members of the Saint Patrick's Battalion.) <Cooper Roh, History - American - Pre-1865> ~24756~ <Editor: Noah Sheidlower>

13. This play's author played Orgon during the 1669 premiere of its final version. For 10 points each:
[10m] Name this play that ends with a deus ex machina ("DAY-uss ex MACK-ih-nuh") as the King orders that the title religious hypocrite be arrested instead of Orgon.
ANSWER: Tartuffe ("tar-TOOF") [or Tartuffe, or the Impostor or Tartuffe, or the Hypocrite or Le Tartuffe, ou l'Imposteur]
[10e] Tartuffe is a play by this author, whose patrons included Louis XIV ("the fourteenth"). This author wrote The School for Wives and The Imaginary Invalid.
ANSWER: Molière ("mohl-YAIR") [or Jean-Baptiste Poquelin]
[10h] The last play in this trilogy, La Mère coupable ("lah mair koo-PAH-bluh"), is subtitled "The Other Tartuffe." The title character exclaims "Just because you are a great nobleman, you think you are a great genius" in the second entry in this Pierre Beaumarchais ("BOH-marsh-ay") trilogy, which was censored throughout Europe.
ANSWER: Figaro trilogy [accept answers indicating a trilogy about Figaro or the Barber of Seville or le Barbier de Séville] (The second entry is The Marriage of Figaro.)

14. Answer the following about figures in Meitei mythology. For 10 points each:
[10m] A divine one of these animals terrorized fishermen of the Khuman kingdom until its capture by Khamba. For rejecting her, Ishtar sends one of these animals to attack Gilgamesh.
ANSWER: bulls [accept Bull of Heaven; reject “cow” or “cows”] (The divine bull is named Kao, pronounced “cow.”)
[10e] The legendary ancestor of the Khuman kingdom, Thongalen, was often syncretized with Yama as a god of this domain. Ammit dwells in this location ruled by Osiris.
ANSWER: underworld [or death; or the dead; or hell; or afterlife; accept Duat or Tuat; or Tuaut; or Akert; or Amenthes; or Amenti; or Neter-khertet]
[10h] In order to win the hand of Shangnu from mortals, the water god Wangpulen competed in three contests, the last of which involved these objects. Bhishma gave advice to both sides of a war while immobilized for over 50 days by these objects.
ANSWER: arrows [accept bow and arrows; prompt on bows alone]

15. This painting was rejected by Les XX ("lay vahn") and features a man in a skull mask among a crowd of grotesque festival goers, many of whom represent real life or allegorical figures. For 10 points each:
[10h] Name this painting in which the title figure rides on a donkey under a banner reading "Vive La Sociale."
ANSWER: Christ's Entry into Brussels in 1889 [accept Entry of Christ into Brussels or L'Entrée du Christ à Bruxelles]
[10e] The artist of Christ's Entry into Brussels, James Ensor, later split with Les XX over their adoption of this technique of using dots to create paintings pioneered by Georges Seurat ("zhorzh sir-AH") and Paul Signac ("see-NYAK").
ANSWER: Pointillism [or Pointillists]
[10m] An odd Ensor still life depicts a series of bottles in front of a person with this relationship on a deathbed. A person with this relationship provides the common name to the painting Arrangement in Grey and Black No. 1.
ANSWER: mother [or mom; accept My Dead Mother or Whistler’s Mother; prompt on family member or parent]
<Juliet Mayer, Fine Arts - Painting - European 1600-1945> ~15072~ <Editor: Ganon Evans>

16. 60 percent of all Pre-Columbian metal production in western Mexico went into making these objects, widely used by Mayan royalty. For 10 points each:
[10m] Name these objects that include the Bonshō found in Buddhist temples in Japan. The Whitechapel Foundry cast the most famous American example of these objects.
ANSWER: bells [accept the Liberty Bell or hand bells or church bells or temple bells; prompt on musical instruments]
[10e] Bonsho are usually made from this metal, which names an "age" that falls between the Stone Age and Iron Age in a system popularized by Christian Jürgensen Thomsen.
ANSWER: bronze [accept Bronze Age]
[10h] Russia's enormous bronze Tsar Bell was commissioned by this ruler. Ernst Johann Biron helped convince this daughter of Ivan V to enter the War of the Polish Succession in 1733.
ANSWER: Empress Anna [or Anna Ioannovna; or Anne; or Anna I; or Anne I]

19. Identify the following about some of the worst Nobel Prizes in medicine, for 10 points each.
[10m] António Egas Moniz won for developing this procedure, which was performed on John F. Kennedy's sister Rosemary in 1941.
ANSWER: lobotomy [or leucotomy]
[10e] Santiago Ramón y Cajal had to share the 1906 prize with this scientist, who had wrong ideas about the nervous system and who names an "apparatus" that packs up proteins into vesicles in eukaryotic cells.
ANSWER: Camillo Golgi [accept Golgi apparatus or Golgi body]
[10h] Johannes Fibiger won in 1926 for "proving" that cancer was caused by these creatures. A different variety of these creatures that cause tiredness and weight loss was combated in the South by the Rockefeller Sanitary Commission.
ANSWER: parasitic worms [or hookworms or roundworms or nematodes or Ancylostoma or Necator; prompt on parasites]

20. After these stars undergo the helium flash, they enter the horizontal branch and then travel along the asymptotic giant branch. For 10 points each:
[10e] Give these post-main sequence stars named for their color and large size. The Sun will become one of these stars before becoming a white dwarf.
ANSWER: red giants [or red giant stars or red giant branch stars; prompt on giant stars]
[10h] AGB stars are named for following the red giant branch of the H–R diagram while undergoing this doubly eponymous process, which causes a star's core to shrink as it radiates energy.
ANSWER: Kelvin–Helmholtz mechanism [or Kelvin–Helmholtz contraction; prompt on answers giving “KH” instead of “Kelvin–Helmholtz”; reject "Kelvin–Helmholtz instability"]
[10m] AGB stars can become Wolf–Rayet stars via a strong form of this phenomenon. The heliopause separates the interstellar medium from a region distinguished by this phenomenon.
ANSWER: stellar wind [or solar wind]
